result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

charges.descr: Operating While Revoked (Rev due to alc/contr subst/refusal 4th+)

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. John Mcmahon Shipp

records.addlTxt:
2:22 PM Defendant John Mcmahon Shipp appeared by video.  Attorney Thomas J McClure Esq appeared by video for John Mcmahon Shipp.  Prosecuting attorney Clifford C. Burdon in court for the State of Wisconsin. 
Atty McClure states that he and the Defendant received a copy of the criminal complaint & waives it's reading. Court advises defendant of maximum penalties.  Defendant understands. 
Defendant waives time limits for the preliminary hearing. 

BY THE COURT:  Defendant waives time limits for the preliminary hearing.
Status hearing scheduled for December 5, 2022 at 02:00 pm.
Status hearing on December 5, 2022 at 02:00 pm.

Adjustment Number: 22A 002360,
Payable Number: 75596,
Receipt Number: 22R 003716,
Amount: $20.00

3:47 PM Defendant John Mcmahon Shipp appeared by video.  Prosecuting attorney Clifford C. Burdon appeared by video for the State of Wisconsin. 
Defendant is making a payment on Friday to the Attorney and asks for another extension.  
Atty Burdon states that the defendant has a Warrant out of Monroe County.

BY THE COURT:  Set AIA in person unless the warrant has been taken care of.
bond continued
Adjourned initial appearance scheduled for October 10, 2022 at 02:00 pm.
Adjourned initial appearance on October 10, 2022 at 02:00 pm.

11:07 AM Defendant John Mcmahon Shipp appeared by phone.  Prosecuting attorney Brian J. Juech appeared by video for the State of Wisconsin. 
Court questions the defendant regarding an attorney.  Defendant did get Atty Avena last week but he could not be here today.  

BY THE COURT:  Reset so Atty Avena can appear with the defendant
Adjourned initial appearance scheduled for September 26, 2022 at 03:30 pm.
Adjourned initial appearance on September 26, 2022 at 03:30 pm.

10:26 AM Defendant John Mcmahon Shipp appeared by video.  Attorney Clifford C. Burdon in court for State of Wisconsin. 
Defendant received a copy of the criminal complaint.  Court confirms address and phone. Court advises defendant of right to an attorney.  Defendant understands and does not qualify for Public Defender so he is working on getting the retainer fee.  

BY THE COURT:  Reset
Adjourned initial appearance scheduled for September 12, 2022 at 10:00 am.
Adjourned initial appearance on September 12, 2022 at 10:00 am.
*No use or possession of any controlled substance without a valid prescription  *Defendant is to submit to a breath test at the request of Law Enforcement with reasonable suspicion of alcohol

3:24 PM Prosecuting attorney Clifford C. Burdon appeared by video for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant John Mcmahon Shipp appeared by video, in custody. Attorney Allison Masrkoski appears as a special appearance on behalf of the defendant for bond. 
Court finds probable cause for the charges for Riverside purposes. 

Atty Burdon requests a $500 Cash bond with conditions.
Defendant makes a statement to the court and is working right now.
Atty Markoski makes bail arguments.

BY THE COURT:  Court sets a $500 Signature bond with conditions: 
*No use or possession of any controlled substance without a valid prescription 
*Defendant is to submit to a breath test at the request of Law Enforcement with reasonable suspicion of alcohol
Initial appearance scheduled for August 22, 2022 at 10:00 am.
Initial appearance on August 22, 2022 at 10:00 am.
